items.title: Morgan Stanley leads race to underwrite SpaceX IPO

featured_image.name: SpaceX’s Next Big Launch Could Be an I.P.O.

items.description:
Morgan Stanley is emerging as the front-runner to secure a key underwriting role in SpaceX's highly anticipated initial public offering, positioning itself ahead of rivals Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan in what could become one of the largest public listings in history, according to sources familiar with the matter[1][2][3].

The bank's long-standing relationship with SpaceX CEO Elon Musk, dating back at least 15 years, gives it a significant edge in the competitive selection process known as a "bake-off," three sources told Reuters[1][2]. However, no banks have been finalized, and it remains uncertain whether Morgan Stanley will secure the coveted "lead left" underwriting position[1][2].

items.title: Lockheed, L3Harris win billions in satellite defense deals

featured_image.name: Lockheed Secures $2.3B NASA Contract to Develop NOAA GeoXO ...

items.description:
The Space Development Agency announced that Lockheed Martin and L3Harris Technologies secured major contracts to build missile tracking satellites as part of a broader $3.5 billion effort to counter advanced weapons threats[1][2].

Lockheed Martin received a contract worth more than $1 billion to build 18 space vehicles for the Tranche 3 Tracking Layer, while L3Harris won an $843 million award for an identical number of satellites[3][4][1]. The awards mark the latest expansion of the Pentagon's Proliferated Warfighter Space Architecture, a layered network of defense satellites in low Earth orbit designed to detect and track conventional and hypersonic missile threats[5][1].

items.title: Global markets crush U.S. stocks by widest margin since 2009

featured_image.name: Emerging markets set to outperform US stocks as dollar weakness continues, Cambridge says

items.description:
Artificial intelligence companies captured Wall Street's attention in 2025, but investors who diversified abroad reaped even bigger gains, as international markets delivered their strongest performance against U.S. stocks in more than three decades.

Nvidia, Tesla, and Palantir Technologies emerged as the most-viewed ticker pages on Yahoo Finance this year, with Nvidia alone attracting a quarter billion page views[1]. The AI chipmaker gained 30% in 2025, while Palantir soared 140%[1]. Despite the intense interest in U.S. tech stocks, the S&P 500 rose just 15% through December 18[2], trailing far behind international benchmarks.

items.title: States split on adopting Trump tax cuts for tips, overtime

featured_image.name: IRS issues guidance on tax on tips and overtime income for 2025

items.description:
As state legislatures prepare to reconvene in January, a fiscal showdown is taking shape over whether to implement President Donald Trump's federal tax deductions for tips and overtime pay, with only one state so far embracing the changes while several others have explicitly rejected them.

The tax breaks, part of Trump's "One Big Beautiful Bill Act" signed into law on July 4, allow workers to deduct up to $25,000 in tips and $12,500 in overtime pay from their federal income taxes through 2028[1][2]. But the benefits depend on whether states choose to adopt parallel deductions—a decision that could cost state budgets hundreds of millions of dollars annually while already facing increased costs from federal Medicaid and food assistance mandates[1][3].

items.title: Ukraine strikes Russian shadow fleet oil tanker in Mediterranean

featured_image.name: Russia unleashes attack on Ukraine as diplomatic talks continue

items.description:
Ukraine's Security Service (SBU) struck a Russian shadow fleet tanker in neutral waters of the Mediterranean Sea on Friday, marking the first time the agency has hit such a target at such a distance from Ukrainian territory. The SBU's Alpha unit used aerial drones to strike the QENDIL tanker more than 2,000 kilometers from Ukraine, according to sources within the intelligence agency[1][2][3][4][5][6][7][8].

The tanker was empty at the time of the attack and sustained critical damage, rendering it unable to be used for its intended purpose, an SBU source told news outlets[1][2][4][5]. The operation represents an unprecedented expansion of Ukraine's reach against Russian economic targets, demonstrating Kyiv's growing capability to strike Russian assets far beyond the immediate conflict zone.

items.title: NUS achieves breakthrough in commercial solar cell durability

featured_image.name: NUS develops perovskite solar cells with conversion ...

items.description:
Researchers at the National University of Singapore have successfully applied vapor deposition to industrial silicon wafers for the first time, producing perovskite-silicon tandem solar cells that surpass 30 percent efficiency and maintain stable operation for over 2,000 hours[1][2][3]. The breakthrough, published today in Science, marks a critical step toward commercial deployment of next-generation solar technology.

The method developed by Assistant Professor Hou Yi and his team at the Solar Energy Research Institute of Singapore overcomes a longstanding manufacturing barrier: forming high-quality perovskite films on the micrometre-scale pyramid textures found in commercial silicon wafers[1][2][3]. While vapor deposition has been recognized as scalable and industry-friendly, it had never successfully produced stable perovskite layers on true industrial silicon with large surface textures until now[1][2][3].

items.title: US, China unveil AI weather models in parallel push

featured_image.name: Can AI help forecasters better predict destructive hurricanes?

items.description:
The United States and China unveiled advanced artificial intelligence-driven weather forecasting systems this week in parallel announcements, marking a significant technological shift in global meteorology as both nations race to harness machine learning for more accurate and efficient predictions.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration made its AI models operational on December 17, while China's Meteorological Administration announced new systems and upgrades between December 17 and 18[1][2][3]. The near-simultaneous launches represent independent developments rather than coordinated efforts, though both aim to revolutionize weather prediction through similar AI approaches[4][5][6].

items.title: Visa, Mastercard settle ATM fee lawsuit for $167.5M

featured_image.name: DOJ granted brief stay in Visa debit case

items.description:
Visa and Mastercard have agreed to pay $167.5 million to resolve a class-action lawsuit alleging they conspired to keep ATM access fees artificially high, according to a settlement filed Thursday in federal court in Washington[1][2][3].

The proposed agreement, which requires judicial approval, would compensate millions of ATM users who paid unreimbursed fees to withdraw cash from independent, non-bank ATMs. Visa would contribute approximately $88.8 million while Mastercard would provide around $78.7 million to the settlement fund[2][3][4]. Eligible customers include those who conducted qualifying ATM transactions dating back to October 2007[2][3][5].

items.title: Trump defends economy as approval hits historic low

featured_image.name: Trump's approval rating slips to 39%, economy weighs, Reuters/Ipsos poll finds

items.description:
President Donald Trump is intensifying his campaign to reassure Americans about the nation's economic health, capping a week of concerted messaging with a Friday evening speech in Rocky Mount, N.C., as polls show growing public dissatisfaction with his handling of affordability issues[1][2][3].

The North Carolina visit follows Trump's prime-time address Wednesday from the White House, where he claimed he inherited "a mess" and insisted "we're poised for an economic boom, the likes of which the world has never seen"[4][5]. The president has sought to blame his predecessor for ongoing price pressures while touting drops in inflation and promising relief ahead.

items.title: US suspends diversity visa lottery after campus shootings

featured_image.name: US Homeland Security orders pause of DV1 visa program

items.description:
In the wake of a campus massacre at Brown University and the killing of an MIT professor, the Trump administration has ordered an immediate pause of the Diversity Immigrant Visa lottery, abruptly halting a program that has offered up to 50,000 green cards each year to immigrants from countries with historically low rates of migration to the United States.[1][2] Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem announced late Thursday that she had directed U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) to suspend the so‑called DV1 program “to ensure no more Americans are harmed by this disastrous program.”[3][4][2]

The move marks one of the clearest breaks yet with three decades of bipartisan support for the diversity visa system and adds a new front to a wider administration crackdown that has already slowed or frozen multiple immigration pathways in recent months.[5][6][7]

items.title: Google Cloud, Palo Alto ink nearly $10B AI security deal

featured_image.name: Google Cloud anticipates at least $58 billion revenue boost ...

items.description:
Alphabet's Google Cloud division and Palo Alto Networks announced Friday an expanded partnership valued at nearly $10 billion, marking the cloud provider's largest security services agreement as enterprises rush to protect AI infrastructure from escalating cyber threats[1][2][3].

The multiyear contract includes Palo Alto's commitment to migrate key internal workloads to Google Cloud and develop new AI-powered security offerings, according to a source with direct knowledge of the matter who spoke to Reuters[1][2][4]. While executives from both companies declined to comment on specific financial figures, the agreement significantly expands a strategic relationship that dates to 2018[1][2][4].

items.title: Interstellar comet makes closest approach to Earth

featured_image.name: An interstellar comet is passing by Earth tonight—here’s how to see it

items.description:
Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS passed closest to Earth early Friday morning, zooming within 168 million miles of our planet at 1 a.m. EST before continuing its journey out of the solar system forever[1][2]. The rare celestial visitor, which originated from beyond our sun's influence, offered astronomers their best opportunity to study an object from another star system.

The comet, discovered July 1, 2025 by the ATLAS telescope survey in Chile, is only the third known interstellar object to pass through our solar system, following 1I/'Oumuamua in 2017 and 2I/Borisov in 2019[3][4][1]. Despite traveling at more than 140,000 mph, 3I/ATLAS posed no threat to Earth, passing at nearly twice the distance between Earth and the sun[3][1].

items.title: Putin says Russia made Ukraine compromises, awaits response

featured_image.name: Putin can fund Ukraine war for years to come, ex-official says as Trump's resolve is tested

items.description:
Russian President Vladimir Putin stated Friday that Russia made compromises on Ukraine during his August summit with U.S. President Donald Trump in Alaska and is now waiting for a response from the West and Kyiv, while the Kremlin leader showed no signs of softening his territorial demands[1][2].

Speaking at his annual end-of-year press conference on December 19, Putin claimed that Moscow had been asked to make certain concessions during the Alaska meeting and agreed to them[1][2]. "The ball is in the West's and Ukraine's court," Putin said, suggesting it is now up to Ukraine and Western nations to respond to Russia's proposed compromises[1][3][4]. He praised Trump's approach to the conflict, stating the U.S. president is making "frank efforts to end the conflict" in Ukraine[1][5][6].

items.title: US stocks rise as inflation data eases Fed concerns

featured_image.name: S&P 500 futures are little changed after index ends four-day losing run: Live updates

items.description:
US stock futures climbed Friday morning, extending a powerful rally driven by unexpectedly soft inflation data and renewed optimism in artificial intelligence stocks following blockbuster earnings from memory-chip maker Micron Technology[1][2][3].

Futures for the S&P 500 rose 0.3%, while contracts for the Nasdaq 100 gained 0.5% as of Friday morning, aiming to build on Thursday's sharp gains[2][3]. The Dow Jones Industrial Average futures held near unchanged levels[2].

items.title: Maersk ship navigates Red Sea for first time in two years

featured_image.name: Maersk completes first Red Sea voyage in nearly two years

items.description:
Danish shipping giant Maersk announced Friday that one of its vessels successfully navigated the Red Sea and Bab el-Mandeb Strait for the first time in nearly two years, marking a cautious step toward resuming a critical global trade route that has been largely abandoned since Houthi militants began attacking ships in early 2024.

The Singapore-flagged container ship Maersk Sebarok completed the transit on Thursday and Friday, the company said in a statement[1][2][3]. However, Maersk emphasized it has no immediate plans to fully reopen the route, with no additional sailings currently scheduled.

"Whilst this is a significant step forward, it does not mean that we are at a point where we are considering a wider East-West network change back to the trans-Suez corridor," the company said[1][4][3]. Maersk indicated it may continue a "stepwise approach" toward resuming passage through the waterway.

items.title: EU delays Mercosur trade pact amid protests, approves $90B for Ukraine

featured_image.name: BELGIUM-AGRICULTURE-POLITICS-DEMO

items.description:
The European Union delayed signing a historic free-trade agreement with South American nations until January, bowing to violent farmer protests and opposition from France and Italy during a critical summit where leaders also secured €90 billion in financing for Ukraine's war effort.

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen announced Friday morning that the EU-Mercosur deal, originally scheduled to be signed in Brazil this weekend, would be postponed to address remaining concerns from member states[1][2][3]. The delay came hours after more than 10,000 farmers descended on Brussels with tractors, blocking roads and clashing violently with police outside EU headquarters where leaders were meeting[1][4].

items.title: Putin holds marathon news conference as peace talks stall

featured_image.name: Live updates: Vladimir Putin holds annual live event as Trump pushes for Ukraine peace deal

items.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin held his annual end-of-year news conference on Friday, addressing around 700 journalists and millions of questions from the public in a televised event that combined his traditional press briefing with a call-in show[1][2][3]. The marathon session came as diplomatic efforts by President Donald Trump to broker a Ukraine peace deal have reached an impasse, with Putin showing little willingness to compromise on his territorial demands.

items.title: Nike profits tumble as China sales fall for sixth straight quarter

featured_image.name: Nike posts surprise sales growth, but warns of sluggish holiday season and bigger than expected tariff hit

items.description:
Nike reported a sharp 32 percent decline in quarterly profits on Thursday as sales in China fell for the sixth consecutive quarter, sending shares plunging nearly 11 percent in after-hours trading and underscoring the challenges facing the sportswear giant's turnaround efforts[1][2][3][4][5].

The company posted net income of $792 million, or 53 cents per share, for its fiscal second quarter ended November 30, down from $1.16 billion a year earlier[3][6][7]. Revenue rose 1 percent to $12.4 billion, slightly exceeding analyst expectations of $12.2 billion[8][2][3].

"Nike is in the middle innings of our comeback," CEO Elliott Hill said in a statement[3][9]. "We are making progress in the areas we prioritized first and remain confident in the actions we're taking to drive the long-term growth and profitability of our brands."

items.title: Canada, US to begin free trade talks in January

featured_image.name: Canadian PM Carney says trade talks with US resume after ...

items.description:
Canada and the United States will launch formal discussions in mid-January to review their free trade agreement, Prime Minister Mark Carney announced Thursday following a meeting with provincial leaders. Dominic LeBlanc, Canada's point person for U.S.-Canada trade relations, will meet with American counterparts to begin negotiations ahead of the agreement's mandatory review in July 2026[1][2].

The announcement comes as trade tensions persist between the two nations, with the U.S. maintaining 50% tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminum and 25% on automotive exports[3][4]. Trump suspended sectoral trade talks in October after the Ontario government ran anti-tariff advertisements in the United States[1][5].

items.title: Japan's MUFG invests $4.4B in India's Shriram Finance

featured_image.name: Japan's MUFG buys 20% stake in India's Shriram Finance

items.description:
Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group will acquire a 20 percent stake in Shriram Finance for $4.4 billion, the Indian non-bank lender announced Friday, marking the largest cross-border investment in India's financial sector and underscoring the growing appetite of Japanese banks for the world's most populous nation.

The Mumbai-based company's board approved issuing 471.1 million equity shares at 840.93 rupees each to MUFG Bank through a preferential allotment[1][2][3][4]. The transaction is subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals, including from the Reserve Bank of India and the Competition Commission of India, with an extraordinary general meeting scheduled for January 14, 2026[1].
